title.value: Beyond Predictive Algorithms in Child Welfare
title.justification: The title encapsulates the core focus of the paper, which challenges the effectiveness of predictive algorithms in the child welfare sector and proposes alternatives.
title.quote: Beyond Predictive Algorithms in Child Welfare

extractions.description: This paper examines the limitations of predictive decision-making algorithms in the child welfare sector. By analyzing data from risk assessments and case narratives, the authors investigate the potential benefits of incorporating contextual information from casenotes into decision-making processes. They highlight the shortcomings of current risk assessment scores in predicting discharge outcomes and advocate for the use of narrative data to study and inform child welfare systems.

type.justification: The paper involves quantitative analysis of data from risk assessments and caseworker narratives to draw conclusions about their predictive validity.
type.quote: We quantitatively deconstructed two commonly used RAs from a United States CW agency. We trained classifier models to compare the predictive validity of RAs with and without casenote narratives...

name.justification: The research is centered around the interaction between human decision-making and predictive algorithms in the child welfare sector, a topic closely related to Human-Computer Interaction.
name.quote: Human-centered computing—Human computer interaction (HCI)—Empirical studies in HCI

name.justification: The study specifically addresses the application and impact of predictive algorithms in the child welfare sector, making it a sub-field of research.
name.quote: The US child welfare (CW) sector is one such sector that has extensively adopted PRMs...

name.justification: The research incorporates the use of machine learning models such as Random Forests and Support Vector Machines to evaluate predictions, thus involving the field of Machine Learning.
name.quote: We trained 14 classifier models using support vector machines (SVM) and random forest models...

name.justification: This is one of the classifier models used to evaluate predictive validity of risk assessment scores in the study.
name.quote: Random Forest using RA scores (AAPI scores)

is_contributed.justification: The model itself is not novel but is employed to test predictions within the study.
is_contributed.quote: Random Forest using RA scores (AAPI scores)

is_executed.justification: The model is trained and evaluated as part of the research.
is_executed.quote: We trained 14 classifier models using support vector machines (SVM) and random forest models...

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared to other models like the Random Predictor and Constant Predictor.
is_compared.quote: Table 1: Classification model metrics for the top performing models

referenced_paper_title.justification: The model type refers to the well-known Random Forest algorithm introduced by Breiman.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Random Forests. Machine Learning, 45(1):5–32, Oct 2001. doi: 10.1023/A:1010933404324

name.justification: The SVM is another classifier model utilized in the study to evaluate predictions.
name.quote: We trained 14 classifier models using support vector machines (SVM) and random forest models...

is_contributed.justification: The use of SVM in this context is not novel but serves to provide a basis for analysis.
is_contributed.quote: ...using support vector machines (SVM) and random forest models...

is_executed.justification: The SVM models are trained and tested in the research.
is_executed.quote: We trained 14 classifier models using support vector machines (SVM) and random forest models...

is_compared.quote: Table 3: Performance metrics for trained classifiers using for the seven datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The SVM model used refers to the foundational work on SVMs by Cortes and Vapnik.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Support-vector networks. Machine Learning, 20(3):273–297, Sep 1995. doi: 10.1007/BF00994018

name.justification: The AAPI is one of the risk assessments analyzed in the study for predicting child welfare outcomes.

referenced_paper_title.quote: AAPI onine development handbook the adult-adolescent parenting inventory (AAPI-2). Family Development Resources, Inc, 2010.

name.justification: NCFAS is another key dataset (risk assessment tool) used for analysis in the study.
name.quote: ...scores from the Adult Adolescent Parenting Inventor-2.5 (AAPI) and North Carolina Family Assessment Score (NCFAS)...

referenced_paper_title.value: NCFAS North Carolina Family Assessment Scale Research Report
referenced_paper_title.justification: The NCFAS report provides the necessary context and validation for its use as discussed in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: NCFAS North Carolina Family Assessment Scale Research Report. National Family Preservation Network, pp. 1–22, 2004.
